mxCell.value: While clearing your grandfather's attic, you find an old command line computer.

You leave the computer and continue clearing the attic. Later, your grandfather asks if you found anything interesting. You tell him about the computer, and he smiles wistfully. Before bed that night, you see him throwing the computer into the dumpster.
The fan on the computer kicks out dust as it whirs to life. A single blinking line appears on the screen, waiting for input.

"Unrecognized command."
Did you really think that would work?

"list - show files in the current directory
restart - reboot the machine
info - show details about the system"

"- - -  K-OS v3.2  - - -
This sytem has been modified to support the Kern Systems Lunar Expansion.

Connection: offline
C:\ (2GB/2GB)
It's a picture of a man dressed casually in flip-flops, khaki shorts, and a hawaiian shirt.

It's a text file that reads:

"My dear Robin,

You will probably never see this, but I think I've found a way to transmit this out of here. If it works, and by some miracle you do find this and open it, I'm sorry. I don't know how time passes for you. I don't even know what is reality anymore. I can only hope that you haven't been waiting for me for the 35 years that I've been trying to make it back to you. I love you, and I fear that I won't be able to ever make it back. I gave up on the quest five years ago. I just couldn't keep trying to win. It's not possible. Or maybe I just don't have the capacity. If you are reading this, it's time to move on. Don't waste your time looking for answers. God knows I have. There aren't any. I will yearn for you until my dying breath in this place. If I write too much more the file will be too large to send. You are and forever will be my one and only love. Don't play the game."

A program begins to run and command outputs scroll past as text fills the screen. The computer's fan sounds as if it is under intense strain. The monitor flickers to black, and soon the single light bulb hanging in the attic begins to flicker as well.

As the program runs, the single light in the attic goes out. The computer emits a single "ding", despite having no visible speakers. The monitor reads:
"Welcome to The Game :)"

You get up to unplug the computer when the light goes out. The computer emits a single "ding", despite having no visible speakers. The monitor reads:
"Welcome to The Game."

You look around and realize that you are no longer in an attic. You are in a small stone room, dimly lit by a fire in a hearth. In front of you, the monitor continues to display its welcome message, although it appears not to be plugged into anything.
You try to type, but the welcome message remains static. It seems you cannot do any further commands while the game is running.

You type "exit". Below the welcome message, a second line of text appears that reads:
"The game must be completed."
The screen goes black.
A brick hearth houses a small but lively fire. There is no obvious source of fuel.

Overcome by an overwhelming urge of stupidity and masochism, you stick your hand into the lit fire.
You receive second degree burns.
You approach the fire and notice that the embers coming off look different than those you've seen before. They have a slight sparkle to them.

You look more closely around the room and discover a thick wooden door with a metal ring handle. In the dark, it almost disappears into the wall. It looks like it hasn't been opened in a very long time.
You approach the fire and notice that the embers coming off look different than those you've seen before. They have a slight sparkle to them.

You hover your hand above the fire and let the glittering embers hit it. A tingling sensation comes over your hand, and the pain from your previous burns subsides. In fact, the wounds have nearly disappeared. The fire goes out.
Put your hand back in the fire.
You put your burnt hand back into the fire and it now begins to burn on its own. You dance around the room in pain as your crispy hand continues to burn.

You stand up to look around the room, when you hear a loud SLAM. A door that you hadn't noticed hits the stone wall with significant force. A rather sturdy man with a grey beard and lustrous hair stands in the door way. He growls,
"WHO HAS DISTURBED THE FIRE?"

He responds, still loudly, but obviously less intimidated upon hearing you speak:
"Who are you? How did you get in here?"
"I... I don't know. I was on that computer and then..."
You dash towards the door, only to collide with the man. You bounce off of his wall-like figure and hit your head on the ground. As you slip into unconsciousness, you feel the man pick you up.

He interrupts you.
"Hmph. I understand. I'm sorry for my entrance, it's been a very long time since someone like you came through. I'm Earl. I go by Big Earl, though."

You are in a small, cozy, cottage. You can make out a lake through the window. You are in large armchair, made of what appears to be some kind of animal hide. It's very soft. The man speaks again.
"Sorry for what happened back there... you were quite spooked. It's not too safe in that area at night, so I brought you back to my house. Name's Earl, by the way. Big Earl."

"Ah. I see you are a wise man. Well, since the gatekeeper isn't around anymore...I'll get you started. I can't explain much to you now, though. You will have to figure that out on your own. Nobody knows how to win. But I can direct you to people who know more than me. First, you need to get a weapon to protect yourself. Are you more skilled with a sword, or a bow?"

You pull the handle, and the door creaks and moves a bit. With some force, the door swings open in a cloud of dust. You step out into a forest. Daylight streams through the canopy and shows a worn path leading out of the room through the trees.

You follow the path through the forest. You hear strange, bird-like sounds from all around, but you can't see what's making them. The trail winds and twists through the woods, and eventually you see a break in the trees. By now, it is late day. The trail turns to cobblestone as it opens into a field. Ahead, you can see the town.

You ignore the path and walk directly into the trees. As you walk, the canopy cover quickly increases and the forest becomes dense. Little sunlight reaches the ground.  You have almost lost sight of the path.
You go deeper into the woods. It is now almost pitch black. You hear shuffling noises in the growth around you.

As your hand cooks, you hear a loud SLAM. A door that you hadn't noticed hits the stone wall with significant force. A rather sturdy man with a grey beard and lustrous hair stands in the door way. His look of anger disappears as he sees you rolling on the floor, clutching your hand.

He laughs at you, and grabs you by the wrist. With one hand he pulls you off the ground. Before you can protest, he brings your hand over the fire. You wince, but notice that the embers are only tingling your hand. Your charred hand returns to its healthy state and the pain subsides.

The man grunts. He speaks with disapproval and brevity:
"You should leave here. Follow the path through the woods. Have haste, you don't want to be in those woods when it gets dark."
The man leaves before you can say anything. You wish you had gotten his name.
You step out into a forest. Daylight streams through the canopy and shows a worn path leading out of the room through the trees.

You turn around to go back and realize that you can't tell which direction you came from. You start walking towards where you think the path was. You can't find it. You start running. There are footsteps behind you. You begin to sprint, but trip over a large root. You fall and hit your head on a tree. As you lose consciousness, you feel a quite large pair of hands pick you up off the ground.
The woods become increasingly ominous as you walk. Strange sounds put you on edge, but you can't see any creatures in the dark.

You wake up in what appears to be a cottage. It's night-time. The man is knitting something in a rocking chair in front of a glittering fireplace. He sees you.
"Hey you, you're finally awake."

"I'm just doing my duty. Since the gatekeeper hasn't been around for a while, someone's gotta handle the newcomers...you seem confused. It's best not to ask questions now. You'll figure them out on your own soon enough. You should get going before it gets dark. There's a town just east of here. I can bring you there and have you meet some people that will help you on your journey."

You follow the road into a town full of stone-brick buildings with thatch roofs. Thick columns of smoke billow out from their chimneys. Out on the street, various merchants have stands set up that are selling all kinds of odd creatures and objects you've never seen before.
"You'll learn more soon. For now, just know that there are certain things that you need to.

He grabs two long sticks off the wall. One is red, one is blue. They look like they could do some damage.
He opens the door and walks out.
